description: Borrowed from French torrent, from Italian torrente, from Latin torrentem, accusative of torrēns (“burning, seething, roaring”), from Latin torrēre (“to parch, scorch”).

adjectives.description: torrent (comparative more torrent, superlative most torrent)

entries.meaning: Rolling or rushing in a rapid stream.
A violent flow, as of water, lava, etc.; a stream suddenly raised and running rapidly, as down a precipice.
examples: Rain fell on the hills in torrents.
A torrent of green and white water broke over the hull of the sail-boat.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) A large amount or stream of something.
examples: They endured a torrent of inquiries.

description: From BitTorrent and the file extension it uses for metadata (.torrent); ultimately from etymology 1.

entries.meaning: (Internet, file sharing) A set of files obtainable through a peer-to-peer network, especially BitTorrent.
examples: I got a torrent of the complete works of Shakespeare the other day; I'm not sure why.

verbs.description: torrent (third-person singular simple present torrents, present participle torrenting, simple past and past participle torrented)

entries.meaning: (Internet slang, transitive) To download in a torrent.
examples: The video rental place didn't have the film I was after, but I managed to torrent it.
